snippet: An earthquake devastated L’Aquila, Italy, in April 2009. But magical thinking is more prevalent there than new ideas for reconstituting the city’s homes.
abstract: Michael Kimmelman asserts that L’Aquila, town in central Italy still in ruins after 2009 earthquake, may offer cautionary tale for New York City post-Hurricane Sandy; warns that L'Aquila's resistance to large-scale infrastructural change, which has kept city mired in rubble, could happen in New York if people are unwilling to plan ahead for next disaster.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake devastated L’Aquila, Italy, in April 2009. But magical thinking is more prevalent there than new ideas for reconstituting the city’s homes.

headline.seo: In L’Aquila, Italy, Lessons for Rebuilding From Storm
headline.main: In Italian Ruins, New York Lessons
